edge: The film is named after Article 15, which is a part of the Constitution of India.
Anubhav Sinha is the director and producer of the film 'Article 15'.
Ayushmann Khurrana is the lead actor in the film 'Article 15'.
The film is inspired by multiple real-life cases involving crimes driven by caste-based discrimination, including the 2014 Badaun gang rape allegations.
The film explores the issue of caste-based oppression, which is prohibited by Article 15 of the Constitution of India.
Article 15 of the Constitution of India prohibits caste-based oppression.
Laalgaon is a village where the incident of two Dalit girls being trapped in a school bus by some men occurs.
Ayan Ranjan is assigned to Laalgaon as the Additional Superintendent of Police.
Brahmadatt Singh warmly welcomes Ayan Ranjan and another officer, Kisan Jatav, in Laalgaon.
Kisan Jatav warmly welcomes Ayan Ranjan and another officer, Brahmadatt Singh, in Laalgaon.
Ayan Ranjan encounters various forms of caste discrimination as soon as he arrives in the village.
Ayan Ranjan's wife, Aditi, is mentioned in the context and she shares what Ayan observes about caste discrimination with him over the phone.
Local villagers come to Ayan's reception asking the officers to find the missing girls but are turned down.
Ayan Ranjan's college friend, Satyendra Rai, also a state government employee, behaves suspiciously throughout the night.
Brahmadatt's attempt to push a narrative suggesting that the girls, who were cousins, were lesbian lovers in an incestuous relationship and thus hanged by their fathers as an honour killing.
Evidence from the girls' autopsy reveals that they were gang raped.

node_2: threatened and their vehicle set on fire by followers of nishad
edge: Followers of Nishad, leader of Bhim Sangharsh Sena (BSS), a group of activists within the village, threatened Jatav and set his vehicle on fire as they seek speedy justice for the crime.
Brahmadatt ordered to obtain an FIR for the case.

Gaura's sister informed Ayan that the girls worked for Anshu Naharia, who slapped Pooja after they asked for a raise in their salary. Anshu explained to Ayan during interrogation that he slapped the girls to remind their entire caste of their place in society due to their birthplace and caste.
Ayan posted a copy of Article 15 of the Constitution of India on the police bulletin board in response to the moral corruption and caste-based discrimination he witnessed in the village.
Meets with Dr. Malti Ram to uncover the truth about the girls' deaths, realizes that local law enforcement is conspiring to cover it up
Reveals to Ayan that the girls were raped and then murdered, asks him to help her investigate further

node_2: head of the laalgaon dalit community
edge: Forms an alliance with as a show of inter-caste unity, Nishad sees it as a political ploy
Refuses to cancel his protest against Mahantji's actions, allows some of his men to help Ayan search for Pooja
Gets a call from Malti confirming that Anshu was among the rapists and gang-murderers
Is not present at his house when Ayan raids it, but Ayan finds evidence of girls' torture and rape in the nearby school
Provides protection to Anshu, kills him when caught by Ayan
Panikar arrives in Laalgaon and suspends Ayan from the case, but Ayan refuses to give up.
Satyendra admits that he witnessed Anshu, Brahmadatt, and police officer Nihal Singh rape the girls while severely drunk at a party hosted by Anshu.
Jatav arrests Brahmadatt on Ayan's command.
Nihal Singh works closely with Ayan, and witnesses Anshu, Brahmadatt, and Nihal Singh rape the girls while severely drunk at a party hosted by Anshu.
Ayan reveals he has already submitted all his evidence to the Home Minister.
Panikar attempts to threaten Ayan into dropping the case, but Ayan sharply criticizes the bigotry and injustice against people of lower castes among Indian law enforcement.
Pooja's statement leads to Brahmadutt getting eleven years of imprisonment as punishment.
Mahantji wins the election, hands down.

This film became available for streaming on Netflix in August 2019.
